title-group.article-title: MTHFR C677T Polymorphism and Recurrent Early Pregnancy Loss Risk in North Indian Population

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Molecular & Human Genetics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
2Department of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Institute of Medical Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India

author-notes.corresp: Kiran Singh, Department of Molecular & Human Genetics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi 221005, India Email: singhk4@rediffmail.com

abstract.p: Recurrent early pregnancy loss (REPL) is a multifactorial disorder as both genetic and environmental factors contribute to the development of disease. Folate metabolism is an important mechanism to ensure proper fetal growth. Hyperhomocysteinemia leads to a number of disorders and REPL is one of them. In a case–control study DNA from 106 cases with the history of 3 or more REPL and 140 healthy fertile controls with successful pregnancy outcomes were genotyped for C677T single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) of the MTHFR (methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase) gene through polymerase chain reaction–restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP), which was further confirmed by sequencing. Allele frequencies of REPL cases were compared with healthy controls and a statistically significant association was found between REPL and the mutant T allele (χ2 = 8.786, odds ratio [OR] = 2.20, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.323-3.9658, P = .003). The genotype frequencies of SNP C677T also differ significantly between these 2 groups (χ2 = 8.237, P = .016). The OR for heterozygous CT in the REPL versus controls is 1.9591 (95% CI = 1.0285-3.7318, P = .04). The OR for TT homozygous is 6.3009 (95% CI = 1.2065, P = .02). Combined odds ratio of CT and TT against the control has been calculated as 2.2194 (95% CI = 1.2029-4.0952, P = .02) which is also significant. Thus the present study clearly indicates that homozygosity and heterozygosity for the MTHFR C677T polymorphism confer a 6.3009- and 1.9591-fold increased risk of idiopathic REPL, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recurrent early pregnancy loss (REPL) is a multifactorial disorder which includes coagulation disorders, autoimmune defects, endocrine disorders, and endometrial defects. 1 In all, 50% cases of REPL are idiopathic with no known factors. Approximately 5% of couples trying to conceive have 2 consecutive miscarriages and approximately 1% of couples have 3 or more consecutive losses.

Proper development of blood vessel in the maternal and fetal interface is required for the exchange of nutrients, gases, and other metabolites through the extra-embryonic coelomic cavity via yolk sac to the embryo. 2 Folate metabolism is considered an imperative mechanism for proper fetal development and successful fetal outcome. Vitamin B deficiency can also result in mild hyperhomocysteinemia. Elevated homocysteine concentration is considered a cause for defective chorionic villi vascularization. 3 One of the causative factors associated with REPL is the aberrant expression of angiogenesis-related genes in the maternal–fetal interface resulting in improper development of embryo. 4 Homocysteine inhibits endothelial cell proliferation, which is closely related to angiogenesis. MTHFR (methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase) enzyme is known to maintain the level of homocysteine in the blood. 5 Increased level of homocysteine in the blood acts as risk factor for a number of disorders which include atherosclerosis, venous thrombosis, neural tube defects, placental abruption or infarction, preeclampsia and so on. 6
–10 Hyperhomocysteinemia has also been found to be associated with the risk of REPL in a population of the Netherland. 11

MTHFR converts homocysteine into methionine, the precursor of S-adenosylmethionine which is a universal donor of methyl group for DNA methylation. 12 DNA methylation plays an important role in gene expression. Abnormal activity of this enzyme can be thought to affect the vascularization and impair the development of embryo. 3 However, a small study reported the toxic effect on embryo rather than affecting methylation. 13 In normal first trimester pregnancies low extra-embryonic coelomic total homocysteine concentration and high folate and methionine concentrations have been reported. 3 MTHFR catalyses the reduction of 5,10-methylenetetrahydrolate to 5-methyltetrahydrofolate. 5-Methyltetrahydrofolate converts homocysteine to methionine. 5 The C677T polymorphism of MTHFR gene affects the enzyme activity. 14,15 MTHFR 677 TT genotype carriers have approximately 30% of the enzyme activity in vitro as compared with the MTHFR 677 CC genotype, and MTHFR 677 CT genotype shows nearly 65% of normal enzyme activity. 14

In the present study, we have evaluated the association between maternal genotype of single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) C677T of MTHFR gene and REPL. We hypothesized that a genotype associated with a decreased activity of MTHFR could be linked with impaired/incomplete angiogenesis which may lead to REPL phenotype.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The present study enrolled 123 primary aborter women who had 3 or more trimester miscarriages before 12 weeks of gestation and 140 healthy fertile women with successful pregnancy outcome as controls. Patients were recruited from the outpatient department of university hospital, Department of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Institute of Medical Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India. Patients underwent a standardized clinical and laboratory evaluation which included hysteroscopy, paternal and maternal karyotyping, cervical cultures for chlamydia, plasma urea, mycoplasma, a comprehensive hormonal status for hypothyroidism (T3, T4, and thyroid-stimulating hormone [TSH]) and evaluation of antiphospholipid syndrome with anti-β2GP1 antibodies, immunoglobulins M and G, anticardiolipin antibody(ACLA) assessment, and lupus anticoagulant testing. Solid-phase enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was used for assay and the value greater than 10 1 unit IgG phospholipid (GPL) was considered ACLA positive. In all, 17 patients during their clinical and laboratory investigations showed 1 or the other known anomalies and were excluded. Among them 4 represented polycystic ovaries, 3 were ACLA positive, 1 was both LA and ACLA positive, 4 were Toxoplasmosis Other Rubella Cytomegalovirus and Herpes (TORCH) positive, 1 was having cervical incompetency, 1 with arcuate uterus, 1 with septate uterus, and 1 had hypothyroidism. Karyotype analysis revealed 2 patients with abnormal numerical chromosome complement. Two patients had mosaic (46, XX and 45, XO) karyotype. Remaining 106 REPL patients having regular cycles were included in the present study. Patients positive for the above test were excluded from the study. None of them had pregnancy-related complications such as diabetes or hypertension. An age-matched 140 women with no history of previous miscarriage and at least 1 successful pregnancy outcome and no problem of cardiovascular disease were selected as controls for the study. All controls were also recruited from the same outpatient department of university hospital. Questionnaire was maintained for each patient to the record details of their lifestyle, habits, and family history. Informed consent was obtained from every participant in each group before their participation in the study. Approval of the University’s ethical committee for research on human material was obtained.

sec.title: Karyotyping
sec.p: Blood lymphocyte culture was done for each patient and patients showing abnormal chromosome complement were excluded.

sec.title: Genotyping of SNP MTHFR C677T by PCR-RFLP
sec.p: Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood of 106 patients with 46, XX karyotype (2 patients whose karyotype showed numerical chromosomal abnormality were excluded) using standard salting-out procedure. The PCR amplification of MTHFR C667T mutation region was amplified using previously used primer with forward primer (5′-AGGCTGTGCTGTGCTGTTG-3′) and reverse primer (5′-CGCTCTGCAAGTTCTGGA-3′) by PCR. 16 The PCR conditions were 30 cycles of 1 minute at 94°C, 1 minute at 68°C, and 1 minute at 72°C. The 477 base pair (bp) fragment generated was restricted digested with Hinf1 at 37°C for 15 hours. The C allele is cut by the enzyme and gives 425 bp and 52 bp products, whereas the T allele yields 260 bp, 165 bp, and 52 bp products (Figure 1).

caption.p: MTHFR C677T mutation was detected by polymerase chain reaction–restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP). The 477 base pair (bp) was digested with Hinf1. The C allele is cut by the enzyme and yields 425 bp, 52 bp products, whereas the T allele yields a 425 bp, 260 bp, 165 bp, and 52 bp products. Lane 1 shows the 100-bp ladder (New England Biolabs), lanes 2, 3, and 4: CC homozygous; lanes 5 and 6: TT homozygous; lanes 7 and 8: CT heterozygous.

sec.title: Sequencing
sec.p: The PCR product of mutant TT genotype was sequenced with Taq-Dye deoxy-terminator-cycle sequencing kit (Applied Biosystem, California) using an automated genetic analyzer 3130 sequencer to ascertain polymerase chain reaction–restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) results (Figure 2). Reverse primer was used for cycle sequencing. The sequence was aligned and analyzed using AB DNA Sequencing Analysis software (version 5.2).

caption.p: Sequencing chromatogram showing the 3 genotypes of single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) C677T of MTHFR gene. Reverse primer was used for sequencing on the genetic analyzer 3130 automated sequencer. The SNP at position C677T of MTHFR is represented by ⋆. (A) Represent homozygous mutant TT, (B) heterozygous CT, and (C) homozygous wild type CC.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Allele and genotype distribution among groups were evaluated using chi-square (χ 2 ) test or Fisher exact test. The difference in frequencies between the case and control groups was analyzed for statistical significance at the 95% confidence interval (CI) using χ 2 test. The allele frequency of MTHFR genotype was in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Odds ratios (ORs) were calculated and reported within the 95% confidence limits. A P value of <.05 was considered significant in all the analyses. Power of study was calculated using G* power. 17,18

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the present study blood lymphocyte culture and G-banding was done for each patient to analyze chromosomal abnormalities. Two patients showed abnormal numerical chromosome complement. Both had mosaic (46, XX and 45, XO) karyotype, hence both the patients were excluded from the study and their DNA was not subjected for genotyping. The PCR-RFLP analysis was performed to evaluate the genotypes of C677T polymorphism of MTHFR gene in 106 patients and 140 control samples (Figure 1). The power of study was found to be 0.99. The genotype and allele frequencies for C677T polymorphism in the MTHFR gene were compared between the 2 groups (Table 1). For MTHFR C677T polymorphism, T allele frequency in REPL patients was 0.16% and in controls 0.082%. The allele and genotype frequencies of MTHFR C677T genotype were in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. We found homozygosity for the MTHFR C677T polymorphism confers a 6.3009-fold increased risk of idiopathic REPL. Allele frequencies of the C677T polymorphism showed statistically significant difference between the REPL versus control group (χ 2 = 8.786, OR = 2.20, 95% CI = 1.323-3.9658, P = .003). The genotype frequencies of SNP C677T also differ significantly between these 2 groups (χ 2 = 8.237, P = .016). The OR for heterozygous CT in the REPL versus controls is 1.9591 (95% CI = 1.0285-3.7318, P = .04). For TT homozygous, the OR was 6.3009 (95% CI = 1.2065, P = .02). Combined OR of CT and TT against the control has been calculated to 2.2194 (95% CI = 1.2029-4.0952, P = .02) which is also significant. Thus the above result indicates the role of MTHFR C677T SNP in the development of REPL phenotype and it can be used as one of the biomarker in patients having the history of REPL. Early screening of patients with mutant genotypes (677TT and 677CT) and by exogenous folic acid supplementation, the adverse effect of enzymatic deficiency can be reversed. This may prevent fetal loss and lead to successful pregnancy outcome at least in cases where MTHFR enzyme activity deficiency is a critical player.

caption.p: Genotype and allele frequencies of MTHFR C677T single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) among REPL and control groups

fn.p: Abbreviation: REPL, recurrent early pregnancy loss.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we have undertaken a case–control study to investigate the role of MTHFR C677T polymorphisms in susceptibility to REPL in north Indian population. Our study demonstrates strong association of MTHFR C677T polymorphism and REPL. Both cases and controls belonged to the same ethnic background and all shared a common geographic origin, that is north India. MTHFR is the candidate enzyme known to play a crucial role in the methyl group metabolic pathway which is involved in both DNA methylation and DNA synthesis. 5 Hyperhomocysteinemia has been found to have an embryotoxic effect rather than affecting methylation. 13 However, it is also suggested that hyperhomocysteinemia resulted in thrombophilia by circulating monocytes inducing the expression of tissue factor, an initiator of blood coagulation in vivo. 19 Hyperhomocysteinemia is also thought 20 to affect endothelial cell function by promoting leukocyte recruitment which contributes to the initiation and progression of vascular disease through upregulation of the expression and secretion of monocytes chemoattractant protein 1 and interleukin 8.

Our result is consistent with the number of studies done, which suggest the role of C677T SNP of MTHFR gene and REPL risk. 8,21
–26 Histological evidence suggests the placid effect of MTHFR C677T on the risk of placental infarction with fetal growth restriction. 21
–25 The role of MTHFR on placental abruption and/or infarction has been confirmed in a meta-analysis of 8 studies. 8 The association of idiopathic recurrent pregnancy loss and MTHFR has been studied in Middle-European white population. 26 They found that homozygosity for the MTHFR C677T polymorphism confers a 3.7-fold increased risk of idiopathic recurrent pregnancy loss. They also found that carriers of 1 or 2 mutant alleles had significantly higher serum concentrations of homocysteine compared with women with 2 wild type alleles. A similar study in accordance with the present study reported an increased prevalence of the C677T mutation in a cohort of Dutch women with a history of unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss. 27 They found a 3-fold increased risk of recurrent pregnancy loss in women homozygous for the MTHFR T>T genotype. Similarly other groups found an association of MTHFR and recurrent pregnancy loss. 28,29 No association was found in other study between MTHFR 677T>T genotype and idiopathic RPL. 30
–34 It has also been found that homozygosity for MTHFR C677T results in pregnancy loss and other prothrombotic factors act as an additional risk factor. 28

MTHFR polymorphism and its association with recurrent pregnancy loss have also been studied in Indian population but in endogamous group that is among Rajput of North India 35 and in group of women of Andhra Pradesh 36 (pilot study). MTHFR C677T polymorphism showed almost 4.7-fold increased risk of recurrent pregnancy loss in the Rajput population of north India. Mutant genotypes (TT/CT) could have a significant influence on the metabolic phenotype because of very low folate and high homocysteine level in the Indian populations. 37,38 Selective advantage of MTHFR C allele might be physiologically protective and presence of T allele would put the individual at metabolic risk in an Indian population. 39 MTHFR CC genotype may favor normal placentation and vessel development which is crucial for proper exchange of nutrient from mother to fetus. Improper maternal–fetal exchange in patients with MTHFR TT and CT mutant genotypes because of compromised angiogenesis, improper placentation, and vessel development may ultimately lead to fetal loss. It was also found in animal model study that supplementation of folic acid during the early trimester of pregnancy increased the survival of fetus and also the number of fetus. 40,41 Hence, in patients with TT/CT genotype, the folic acid supplementation may improve successful pregnancy outcome.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We conclude that the T allele is significantly associated with the development of idiopathic REPL in a north Indian population. Folic acid supplementation has been found to improve fetal survival in animal model. Hence, it can be exogenously supplemented to improve the survival of fetus in mothers having mutant 677TT and 677CT genotypes. Therefore, the present study signifies the role of C677T SNP of folate metabolic pathway in the development of REPL phenotype. Keeping in view the significant role of MTHFR in vascularization and development of placenta, we suggest that 677C>T SNP of MTHFR gene may be examined as one of the markers for REPL.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We are thankful to all the patients and volunteers for providing blood samples.

fn.p: This work was done at the Department of Molecular & Human Genetics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi-221005, India.
The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Financial assistance was provided by Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technologyy, New Delhi, India.
